title: Growing Up and Growing Old in Scotland: housing transitions and changing living arrangements for young and older adults, 1991-2011
abstractText:
The study investigates the dimensions and determinants of housing transitions and changing living arrangements for young (aged 16-29) and older (aged 55-69) adults in Scotland between 1991 and 2011. In the last few decades, demographic, social and economic changes have resulted in increased diversity across individual life courses and housing careers, while the recent economic downturn is having a disproportionate impact on first time home buyers.

Three research questions address the dimensions of change, the key determinants, and whether social and geographical polarisation has increased over time. Secondary data from Scottish Censuses and the Scottish Longitudinal Study, linked to other data on housing and labour market characteristics, are used in an integrated macro-micro modelling approach to predict living arrangements at the end of each decade for both age groups. Results will provide evidence on the main drivers of decadal change and whether differences between the most advantaged and disadvantaged social groups, and between local areas in Scotland, have widened over time.

The study is the first on Scotland to analyse housing transitions and changing living arrangement for young and older adults within a common analytical framework, and findings will contribute to the evidence base for policy development.
